issues.title: Timing Belt and Balance Shaft Belt Failure
issues.symptoms: Engine won't start, catastrophic engine noise, bent valves, snapped belt visible through timing cover inspection hole
issues.description: The 944's 2.5L (and 2.7L/3.0L in later S and S2 models) inline-4 is an interference engine that relies on timing and balance shaft belts. If either belt fails, the valves will contact the pistons, requiring an engine rebuild or replacement. This is the most critical maintenance item on the 944.
fixes: Replace BOTH timing belt AND balance shaft belt every 30,000 miles or 4 years
Replace timing belt tensioner and rollers
Replace water pump (driven by timing belt)
Replace all timing belt area seals
Use only high-quality belts (OEM, Gates, Continental)
Never buy a 944 without documented timing belt history

repairCosts.notes: BOTH timing and balance shaft belts required. Critical service.

issues.title: Water Pump Failure
issues.symptoms: Coolant leak at front of engine, overheating, squealing noise from engine, play in water pump shaft
issues.description: The 944 water pump is driven by the timing belt and located behind the timing covers. When the pump bearings or seals fail, coolant leaks externally or, worse, internally into the timing belt area where it can contaminate and weaken the belt.
fixes: ALWAYS replace water pump with timing belt service
Use OEM or quality metal-impeller pump
Replace thermostat at the same time
If pump failed between services, inspect timing belt for contamination
Pressure test cooling system after repair

repairCosts.notes: Always do with timing belt. Driven by belt.

issues.title: DME Relay Failure
issues.symptoms: No-start condition, fuel pump doesn't prime, car dies while driving and won't restart, intermittent starting issues
issues.description: The DME (Digital Motor Electronics) relay is an infamous weak point on all 944s. This relay controls power to the fuel pump, fuel injectors, and engine management computer. The relay uses solder joints that crack over time from thermal cycling.
fixes: Replace DME relay with new OEM unit
Avoid cheap aftermarket relays
Some owners re-solder the original relay as temporary fix
Carry a spare relay in the glove box
Clean relay socket contacts while relay is out

issues.title: Clutch Hydraulic System Failure
issues.symptoms: Clutch pedal goes to floor, soft or spongy pedal, difficulty shifting, clutch won't disengage, fluid leak
issues.description: The 944 uses a hydraulic clutch system with a master cylinder at the pedal and a slave cylinder at the transaxle. Both cylinders use rubber seals that deteriorate over time, causing internal and external leaks.
fixes: Replace clutch master cylinder
Replace clutch slave cylinder
Replace clutch hydraulic line if deteriorated
Bleed system thoroughly (use pressure bleeder for best results)
Use DOT 4 brake fluid

repairCosts.notes: Master and slave cylinders both fail with age.

issues.title: Torque Tube Bearing Wear
issues.symptoms: Vibration at certain speeds, humming or growling noise from center of car, vibration when accelerating or decelerating
issues.description: The 944 uses a torque tube to connect the front-mounted engine to the rear-mounted transaxle. The torque tube contains the driveshaft and uses a center support bearing that wears over time, causing vibrations and noise.
fixes: Replace torque tube center support bearing
Inspect CV joints at both ends of the driveshaft
Replace flex disc (guibo) at engine end if cracked
Replace rear CV joint if worn
Have torque tube serviced by specialist if unfamiliar

repairCosts.notes: Center bearing and flex disc (guibo) wear.

issues.title: Dashboard Cracking
issues.symptoms: Cracks appearing on dashboard surface, especially on top near windshield, warping, deteriorating texture
issues.description: The 944 dashboard is made of foam covered with vinyl and is extremely prone to cracking, especially in hot climates or when exposed to direct sunlight. UV exposure causes the vinyl to shrink and crack.
fixes: Dashboard cover or cap (covers damage but changes appearance)
Professional dashboard restoration
Replacement with used dashboard
Custom dashboard replacement panels
Prevention: always use sunshade when parked

repairCosts.notes: All 944 dashes crack. Covers or professional restoration.

issues.title: Power Steering Rack Leaks
issues.symptoms: Power steering fluid leak, low fluid in reservoir, heavy steering when cold, whining from power steering pump
issues.description: The 944 power steering rack commonly develops leaks from the seals as they age. Leaks typically occur at the pinion seal, tie rod end seals, or pressure line connections.
fixes: Rebuild steering rack with new seals
Replace steering rack with rebuilt or new unit
Replace power steering lines if leaking
Replace power steering pump if damaged
Replace tie rod ends while rack is out

repairCosts.notes: Rack seals and pump common failures.

issues.title: Odometer and Speedometer Gear Failure
issues.symptoms: Odometer stops working while speedometer works, intermittent odometer, trip meter stuck
issues.description: The 944 instrument cluster uses plastic gears to drive the odometer from the speedometer. These gears strip or crack with age, causing the odometer to stop functioning while the speedometer continues to work.
fixes: Replace odometer gears with aftermarket repair kit (brass gears available)
Have instrument cluster professionally rebuilt
Replace entire cluster with functional used unit
This is a common DIY repair with proper instructions

repairCosts.notes: Plastic gears strip. Brass upgrade kits available.

issues.title: Engine Mount Deterioration
issues.symptoms: Excessive engine vibration, engine moves visibly during acceleration/deceleration, clunking when shifting
issues.description: The 944 engine is mounted to the chassis with rubber mounts that deteriorate over time. When worn, the engine moves excessively, causing vibrations and clunking noises during load changes.
fixes: Replace engine mounts with OEM rubber mounts
Consider polyurethane mounts for performance use
Replace transaxle mounts at the same time
Check and replace torque tube mounts if worn

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Complete oil and filter change procedure for all 944 engine variants.
tools: Ramps or jack and jack stands
steps: Warm the engine for 2-3 minutes to thin the oil.
Drive onto ramps or raise and support the car safely.
Locate the oil drain plug on the rear of the oil pan.
Position drain pan and remove the 19mm drain plug.
Allow oil to drain completely - 10 minutes minimum.
The spin-on oil filter is located on the passenger side of the engine.
Using the oil filter wrench, remove the old filter.
Apply a thin film of fresh oil to the new filter's rubber gasket.
Thread new filter on by hand until gasket contacts, then tighten 3/4 turn more.
Replace the crush washer on the drain plug.
Reinstall drain plug and torque to 22 ft-lbs (30 Nm).
Add 6.5 quarts (NA) or 7 quarts (Turbo) of 15W-40 or 20W-50 oil.
Start engine and check for leaks at drain and filter.
Shut off, wait 2 minutes, check level, and top off as needed.
tips: The 944 takes 6.5-7 quarts depending on model and oil cooler configuration.
High-zinc oils (15W-40 diesel-rated) are recommended for the flat-tappet cam.
Turbo models should use quality synthetic in hot climates.

diyGuides.title: DME Relay Replacement
diyGuides.description: Replace the notorious DME relay before it leaves you stranded.
steps: The DME relay is located in the central electric panel under the dash, driver's side.
Remove the lower dash panel to access the fuse/relay panel.
Locate the DME relay - it's typically in position XI (11) on the relay board.
The DME relay is the larger relay that controls fuel pump and DME power.
Note the orientation of the relay before removing.
Gently pull the old relay straight out of its socket.
Inspect the relay socket contacts for corrosion - clean if needed.
Push the new relay firmly into the socket in the correct orientation.
Turn key to ON and listen for fuel pump prime (2-3 seconds of pump noise).
Start engine and verify it runs properly.
Reinstall dash panel.
Keep the old relay (if functional) as a spare in the glove box.
tips: The DME relay controls fuel pump, injectors, and DME computer power.
If car dies while driving and won't restart, DME relay is the prime suspect.
Some owners re-solder the original relay's cracked joints as a roadside repair.
Always carry a spare DME relay - this is the most common 944 failure.

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement with rotor inspection.
steps: Loosen lug bolts while the car is on the ground.
Raise and support the car safely on jack stands.
Remove wheel to access the caliper.
Front calipers: Remove the two 7mm Allen caliper guide pin bolts.
Rear calipers: Remove the caliper bracket bolts (varies by year).
Swing or remove the caliper and support it - don't let it hang by the hose.
Remove the old pads from the caliper bracket.
Inspect rotor for scoring, cracks, or minimum thickness.
Clean pad contact areas in the bracket with wire brush.
Open brake fluid reservoir cap, then compress caliper piston.
Apply brake grease to the back of new pads and contact points.
Install new pads in the bracket.
Reinstall caliper and torque bolts to spec (63 ft-lbs for caliper bolts).
Reinstall wheel and torque lug bolts to 96 ft-lbs (130 Nm).
Repeat for all corners.
Pump brake pedal until firm before driving.
tips: The 944 uses solid front rotors on base models, vented on Turbo and S2.
Rear brakes on 944 are cable-operated parking brake - adjust cable after pad change.
Bed in new pads with gradual stops - avoid hard braking for first 100 miles.

diyGuides.title: Timing Belt Inspection
diyGuides.description: Inspect timing and balance shaft belts through the inspection window.
steps: Park the car and allow the engine to cool.
Open the hood and locate the timing belt cover on the driver's side of the engine.
Remove the small inspection cover plate (1-2 10mm bolts) from the upper timing cover.
Using a flashlight, peer through the inspection window.
Examine the visible portion of the timing belt for cracks, glazing, or fraying.
Look for any separation between the belt's teeth and backing.
Check for oil contamination - belt should be dry.
If possible, rotate the engine (by hand at crank bolt) to inspect more of the belt.
Reinstall the inspection cover.
Note: This is only a preliminary check - belts can fail with little visible warning.
If any damage is visible, schedule immediate belt replacement.
Even if belt looks good, replace at 30,000 mile intervals.
tips: This is an interference engine - belt failure destroys valves and pistons.
Oil on the belt means water pump or seal failure - address immediately.
Visual inspection does not replace scheduled belt changes.
Both timing belt AND balance shaft belt must be replaced together.
